text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with bacon ranch chicken skewers
that's right this goes out to all you
tailgaters out there it is football
season and if you want a very extra easy
extra special item for your next
tailgate barbecue this is a great option
and yes you could call these kabobs if
you have to me i'm not going to okay so
step one with any kind of wooden skewer
to item we're gonna soak the bamboo
skewers in water at least two or three
hours better overnight okay so set those
aside to prep the chicken I'm going to
use large chicken breasts alright these
are like the 8 to 10 ounce size
okay the filet is gone the little
chicken finger has been pulled out it's
not really a great shape for this recipe
so you should save those for another
dish or just eat it for a snack and then
we're going to want to cut equal size
chunks so I'm going to start with that
little pointy end of the chicken breast
and take two pieces off that then I'm
going to turn it and I like to cut nice
thick strips like that and then I'll
turn it and I'll cut those into cubes
you're going to get about 12 nice chunks
all right I think I got 13 there alright
but if you shoot for 12 per large
chicken breast you will be in good shape
alright once our chickens cut we're
going to add it to a mixing bowl I'm
going to put in a big spoon of chili
paste you can pretty much use anything
spicy here I'm using that Calabrian
crushed chili paste that I used in a
recipe a while back and then the rest of
the marinade is simply a ranch dressing
that's right and what's a big ingredient
in ranch dressing
buttermilk and what is buttermilk do to
chicken makes it tender and delicious
now I'm showing you a very basic version
as usual of course you're free to add
many many more things to this like fresh
herbs other aromatic spices whatever
you're into alright so once that is well
mixed I'm going to wrap that with
plastic and I'm going to marinate this
for 1 hour minimum to I would say 2 to 3
hours maximum I don't think this should
be over marinated you know what you're
checking to get to soft and mushy all
right so it's an hour later we are ready
to start scaring the only other thing I
need is a couple pieces of onion per
skier I just took a red onion and cut to
pieces
about the same size as the chicken and
here we go we're going to take one skier
and we're going to start with a piece of
onion now one of the secrets to this
technique is stay near the top alright
don't push everything down put your
onion on leave it near the top next goes
the bacon right with a strip starts push
that through then a piece of chicken
once the chickens on I'm going to grab
the bacon I'm going to bring it over to
cover the chicken and then I'm going to
simply turn the skewer so the bacon is
hanging down once the bacon is hanging
down put out another piece of chicken
bring the bacon up over that gets scared
on again I'm turning the skewer so the
bacons hanging down in fact there's an
old saying that you hear professional
bacon ranch chicken skewer makers say if
the Bacon's not hanging down turn this
gear around alright that's how they
remember that so basically we're doing
an over-and-under we've every time we
put a piece of chicken on we turn the
skier and then the bacon goes over all
right and that's it four pieces of
chicken that strip of bacon will be the
perfect length to cover our last piece
of onion goes over the top once it's on
then we want to space it out a little
bit all the ingredients should be
touching but you don't want it super
super tight smush together we need the
heat to get in there and cook all those
pieces evenly so that's just about
perfect so I'm just doing six skewers
here that's two chicken breasts
you can totally scale this recipe for as
bigoted alligators you're going to do
all right so at that point I was ready
to grill if you want you can season with
salt and pepper lightly here all right
some people think the bacon will give it
enough saltiness depends on how highly
seasoned your ranch dressing is all
right so you gotta play that by ear
we're gonna head out to the grill where
I have a very mature fire
alright see those coals are white those
are cooked down I would describe this as
a medium heat you don't want something
just super super intense it will cook
too fast the bacon will burn but you
also want something you know
hot enough to caramelize so I'm going to
place my chicken down right across the
center and then I love this extra little
trick here yes we soaked our skiers but
to guarantee a beautiful presentation
I'm going to put a strip of folded up
foil on the bottom underneath the skier
and another piece on top underneath that
delicate tip that way just the chicken
cooks and the wood stays beautiful and
unburnt now these are going to go about
three minutes per side and there's four
sides okay there's not two sides so
you're going to figure out in between I
don't know twelve and fifteen minutes
but of course it really depends it
really depends on your heat and how
tightly you pack them and how big you
cut it so of course you're going to use
a thermometer if you have to double
check one great advantage of the foil
you can actually turn these by hand the
bottom of that skier is not hot at all
so it's very easy to turn that and make
sure you're getting all those sides
evenly cooked twelve to fifteen minutes
later you should have beautiful
beautiful bacon ranch chicken skewers
the exposed bacon will be browned the
chicken will be cooked it will be juicy
succulent
and I predict delicious and there we go
how did it taste it tasted like bacon
and ranch marinated chicken which tastes
really good and in fact you get to
experience the bacon two ways the
outside of the bacon gets crispy and
crusty and salty and caramelized and
then the bacon inside that's touching
the chicken stays soft and succulent and
a little fatty which adds another
dimension to this dish so I really
really love this technique and come on
